name: Graz
fun_fact: Fun fact: Graz was named Austria's 'Capital of Delights' and hosts more Michelin-starred restaurants per capita than almost any Austrian city - in 2023, it hosted the entire MICHELIN Guide Ceremony for all Nordic countries.

hero_dishes.name: K√§ferbohnensalat
hero_dishes.description: Scarlet runner bean salad dressed with pumpkin seed oil, vinegar, and onions - simple but unforgettable nutty flavors
hero_dishes.origin_story: K√§ferbohnen (scarlet runner beans) grow exclusively in Styria's five specific regions around Bad Radkersburg, Feldbach, Weiz, Hartberg and F√ºrstenfeld. These protected beans have been cultivated here for generations, stored year-round and prized for their distinctive nutty taste. They're often enhanced with hard-boiled eggs or peppers.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Stainzerbauer (Graz institution in hidden courtyard serving Styrian classics), Altsteirische Schmankerlstube (historic building with terrace)

hero_dishes.name: Styrian Schnitzel
hero_dishes.description: Traditional schnitzel coated in pumpkin seeds instead of breadcrumbs, finished with pumpkin seed oil
hero_dishes.origin_story: Graz chefs took Austria's beloved schnitzel and gave it a distinctly Styrian twist by using the region's 'green gold' - pumpkin seed oil. This innovation celebrates local pride while honoring tradition. 2.5kg of pumpkin seeds makes just one liter of this precious oil.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Altsteirische Schmankerlstube (don't miss this dish), Gl√∂cklbr√§u (18th-century traditional spot in Glockenspielplatz), Landhauskeller

hero_dishes.name: Traditional Styrian Backhendl
hero_dishes.description: Deep-fried chicken with crispy golden coating, served with potato salad
hero_dishes.origin_story: While backhendl exists throughout Austria, Graz's version reflects the region's commitment to quality ingredients - free-range chickens and pumpkin seed oil-dressed potato salad make it distinctly Styrian.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gl√∂cklbr√§u (authentic 18th-century Austrian food in Glockenspielplatz heart of old town), Gasthaus Pichler

hero_dishes.name: Styrian Tapas
hero_dishes.description: Small plates showcasing regional specialties - cured meats, cheeses, bean salads, all featuring pumpkin seed oil
hero_dishes.origin_story: Der Steirer restaurant pioneered 'Styrian Tapas' - adapting the sharing plate concept to showcase Graz's incredible local producers. It's modern presentation of ancient Styrian farming traditions.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Der Steirer (innovative Styrian tapas with extensive wine collection), Aiola Im Schloss (historic mansion on city outskirts)

signature_drinks.name: Styrian Wine
signature_drinks.description: Crisp whites from the S√ºdsteiermark region, especially Sauvignon Blanc and Gelber Muskateller
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Locals treat wine cellars as social clubs. Stainzerbauer's cellar stocks fine and rare wines. Styrian Sauvignon Blanc rivals the best internationally, with mineral notes from the region's unique soil.

signature_drinks.name: Pumpkin Seed Oil Shots
signature_drinks.description: Small shots of pure pumpkin seed oil, Styria's 'green gold' served as a digestif
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: While typically used as a condiment, some traditional restaurants offer small tasting shots of premium pumpkin seed oil. It's thick, nutty, and considered health-promoting. You'll find bottles on every table alongside salt and pepper.

food_culture_notes: Pumpkin seed oil ('K√ºrbiskern√∂l') appears on EVERYTHING in Graz - salads, ice cream, even desserts. It's called 'green gold' and protected by PGI status
Kaiser Josef Platz and Lendplatz host daily farmers' markets with produce from Graz's 800 farms within city limits
The region's long growing season and mineral-rich soil create exceptional vegetables, wild herbs, and berries
Graz earned 'Capital of Delights' status for its commitment to fresh, local ingredients over imported luxury items
